text:
What if we took a step back to consider new 
ways to approach old problems, could we design

cities to better serve the 
communities that live in them?

Could we find ways to use infrastructure like 
data centers, power plants, wastewater treatment

to play a positive role in supporting that vision?
Local community leaders in Tallaght,

a growing area of Dublin, Ireland, have 
come up with a number of solutions.

And at the core is the district heating scheme 
powered by AWS. Revitalization efforts have

created an ideal canvas for district heating 
in Tallaght, where excess heat produced by

data centers is transported across the 
community to heat buildings and water.

Tallaght University Hospital is one of 
the many district heating participants,

but it doesn't stop there. They're also 
using cloud technologies to transform healthcare.

From AI-powered stroke diagnosis 
to case prioritization, machine learning is

transforming the way specialists work. 
Nearby is Technical University Dublin,

another participant in the heating program, 
which also plays a major role in revitalization efforts.

TUD works with the hospital and AWS on 
healthcare hackathons, and runs a data center

technician course. Both initiatives are helping 
to educate the local community in new industries

such as cloud computing. Back at the center 
of Tallaght, AWS has also collaborated with

the County Council to establish a Think Big 
Space. Here, children have the opportunity to

learn and apply basic coding skills to community 
focused ideas. What's more, they can also remotely

collaborate with other Think Big Spaces across 
the world, expanding children's worldview. I

arrived in Tallaght wondering what kind of role 
we could play in the community. It turns out,

quite a helpful one. Our data center sits at the 
center of a really practical network, a network

of data, heat, brilliant minds and community 
members. This level of local interconnection

can be a model for other communities and 
industries everywhere. Now, go build.
